snippet: Wen Jiabao is expressing regrets in his final days as China’s prime minister for falling short of achieving genuine political and economic reforms, but he is also defending his integrity.
abstract: Chinese Prime Min Wen Jiabao has been struggling to push through economic changes and to shore up his image as one of few Communist Party leaders to champion political reform as his retirement looms; Wen has also been pressing hard to clear his name, particularly in months since The New York Times published accounts of way his immediate family had become extraordinarily rich during his time in office.

byline.original: By ANDREW JACOBS and JONATHAN ANSFIELD

lead_paragraph: Wen Jiabao is expressing regrets in his final days as China’s prime minister for falling short of achieving genuine political and economic reforms, but he is also defending his integrity.

headline.seo: China Leader, Wen, Is Regretful but Defensive
headline.main: China’s Premier Admits Failings, but Defends Image
headline.print_headline: In Defensive Stance, a Leader Voices Regret

keywords.value: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
keywords.name: organizations
